Headline.Para: JustSaying; Facebook is free, so we're paying for it

LeadPara.Para: Doing things with personal data is a core business model that society has chosen to support for years
Let me make you an offer upfront: If you make it to the end of this column, I will reveal to you my sure-fire four-step method of ensuring total online data privacy.

TailParas.Para: Before we get to that part though, you have to put up with me lamenting about how we got to a situation where my four-step method is one of very, very few ways you can become a private person again.

I realise that there are already many people out there giving you advice on how to secure your data after the whole Cambridge Analytica-Facebook debacle, but my personal feeling is that those guides are practically worthless.

I mean, the truly private among you will want to keep all aspects of your life private, yet all the advice the other experts are offering is to do things like audit your app permissions or delete your Facebook account.
What good is that?

Sure, deleting Facebook will probably make you feel better; and sure, it will save you from seeing those needy, attention-seeking vague posts like "I can't believe what this person just did to me... don't ask".

Getting rid of Facebook in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica revelations is mostly meaningless - just because the social network may no longer be able to give your data to a suspicious developer, it does not mean some other tech company cannot do it too, says the writer. PHOTO: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

Sure, it will stop you from seeing your friend humble-bragging about her fourth vacation in two months; and sure, it will mean you never having to wade through uninformed opinions about politics and pop culture ("I haven't watched the other films but The Big Sick was ROBBED!").
And sure, it may mean not having to read any posts from Liverpool fans; but other than that, I can't think of any major benefits of deleting Facebook.

Facebook, Google and any tech company that offers you a seemingly free service have become data companies. Their product is your data and their existence depends on their ability to collect your data, do some analysis and then monetise it.

In the grand scheme of things for privacy, getting rid of Facebook is mostly meaningless - it's not even like closing the barn door after the horse has bolted, it's like closing the barn door after a hurricane has blown away the entire barn leaving just the door.

Just because Facebook may no longer be able to give your data to a suspicious developer and then make half-hearted attempts to stop the developer from selling the data, it doesn't mean some other tech giant can't do it too.

After all, doing things to your personal data is the core Silicon Valley business model. And it is the business model we chose and then supported for years when we decided to upend longstanding rules of economics and commerce.
You see, a long time ago, there was hardly anything available for free and commerce was much simpler.

Let's say you are a prehistoric man with a stick but what you really want is a smooth rock. Then you see another prehistoric guy with a rock who seems to be looking around for a stick. What do you do?
Simple, you hit him on the head with your stick and take his rock because other forms of commerce had not yet been invented.
However, after several generations of the violence-based economy, we invented barter and then money and then more complex buying and selling arrangements like credit and Amway.
Despite the innovation, most of it centred on the principle of paying for something you wanted.
Say you wanted some bread, you paid somebody for the cost of ingredients and the labour to make the bread. It was that simple.

Then, some time over the last 20 years, something changed and a completely different system took over. Suddenly, at least where the Internet is concerned, we all wanted our stuff to be free. This applied to things that very clearly cost money to provide like e-mail and social media platforms and, of course, news.
And we wanted it to be free not in the socialist sense where the government would just provide it all; we wanted it to be free while sustaining private enterprise.
So companies - at least the ones with viable business models - had only one choice: Pay for everything with advertising.
In the bread analogy, that meant the baker needing to force anyone who wanted bread to watch an ad for shampoo first so that the shampoo company would pay him to make the bread.
This worked for a while, and then the shampoo company said: "Hey, I don't want to pay to show my ad to all your customers; some of them are bald. I want to advertise to only the hairy hungry people."
So the baker had to start collecting data and building up profiles of the people eating free bread so the bread sponsors could better target them with advertising.
And that's basically the situation we created for ourselves today. Facebook, Google and any tech company that offers you a seemingly free service have become data companies.

Their product is your data and their existence depends on their ability to collect your data, do some analysis and then monetise it. The platform/bread is there only to try and keep you coming back to the shop so they can collect more data.

You can rest assured that nearly everything you do online is being tracked by some company. And unless they are about to upend their own business model or - humour me - some super unlikely strange thing happens where people become willing to pay for things that cost money, then data privacy will continue to be impossible - impossible, that is, unless you follow this four-step method.
Keep in mind that it is hard to stop companies gathering your data and harder still to get rid of the reams of data already harvested, so don't expect this to be something you can achieve quickly.
•Step 1: Join a high-powered criminal organisation.
•Step 2: Witness a murder or other significant crime involving the head of the criminal organisation.

•Step 3: Become an informant for the American authorities and enter the witness protection programme where you will be given an entirely new identity. (You will need to repeat these steps every five years or so to reset the digital footprint.)
•Step 4: And while you're at it, you might as well delete Facebook.
